description: From Middle English assisten, from Old French assister (“to assist, to attend”), from Latin assistō (“stand at, bestand”, verb).

entries.meaning: A helpful action or an act of giving.
examples: The foundation gave a much needed assist to the shelter.

definitionGroups.group: (sports) The act of helping another player score points or goals

entries.meaning: (soccer) A decisive pass made to the goal scorer
examples: Özil has 16 assists in the Premier League and three goals; he has two more goals in the Champions League. On Monday, he took Bournemouth apart in the 2-0 win at the Emirates Stadium, setting up the first for Gabriel and scoring the second himself.

entries.meaning: (baseball) A defensive play, allowing a teammate to record a putout.
examples: He had two assists in the game.

verbs.description: assist (third-person singular simple present assists, present participle assisting, simple past and past participle assisted)

examples: This book will assist you in getting your life in order.
Tutor feedback assists the learning process.

entries.meaning: (sports) To make a pass that leads directly towards scoring.
(medicine) To help compensate for what is missing with the help of a medical technique or therapy.
(archaic) To stand (at a place) or to (an opinion).
examples: A great part of the nobility assisted to his opinion.

entries.meaning: (now archaic) To be present (at an event, occasion etc.).
examples: I assisted with pleasure at the representation of several tragedies and comedies.
